question: The design of the church illustrated was most influenced by <image 1> <image 2>
description:
The first image depicts a floor plan of a large building with a rectangular layout. The structure has a central nave flanked by two side aisles, each separated by columns or piers. At one end of the building, there is a semi-circular apse, which is typically found in churches. The overall design suggests a longitudinal arrangement with a clear division between the nave and the side aisles.

The second image shows a cross-sectional view of a similar building. It features a high central nave with a pitched roof supported by columns or piers. The side aisles are lower than the central nave and have their own roofs. The structure also includes an apse at one end, which is consistent with the floor plan shown in the first image.

Both images depict architectural elements commonly found in basilicas, such as the central nave, side aisles, and apse. Basilicas were originally Roman public buildings used for various civic functions but later adapted for Christian worship. The design elements in these images align closely with the characteristics of basilicas.
